speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the appearance of the chest skin lesion? Is it painful or itchy?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a pretty noticeable bump, about the size of a nickel, and it's been getting a bit larger. It's not painful to the touch, but I have to admit, it's been kind of... annoying that it's getting bigger.

speaker: Doctor
text: Is the lesion raised or flat? Does its color stand out from your surrounding skin?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's raised, actually. The color is a bit darker than the surrounding skin, and it's been getting a bit more noticeable over the past few weeks. It's almost like it's taking on a slightly different hue compared to the rest of my chest."

speaker: Doctor
text: Is the lesion changing in size or appearance over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, it's definitely getting bigger, like I mentioned. It's not really changing color or shape, but it's just getting bigger. I've noticed it's been growing over the past couple of months, and I've been meaning to get it checked out."

speaker: Doctor
text: Has the lesion been present for more than a month? REQUEST TEST: Skin biopsy.

speaker: Doctor
text: Is the lesion affecting only one area of your chest or multiple areas?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's just on my chest, actually. I don't notice anything else like it. It's just this one spot."

speaker: Doctor
text: Is the lesion accompanied by any other symptoms like fever or weight loss?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, nothing like that. Just the growing bump on my chest. I've been pretty symptom-free, to be honest."

speaker: Doctor
text: Is the edge of the lesion clear and defined, or is it blurry?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's pretty clear, to be honest. I can see the edges of it pretty easily. It's not fuzzy or fuzzy around the edges, so I think that's good."

speaker: Doctor
text: Is the lesion causing any discomfort when clothing rubs against it? REQUEST TEST: Skin biopsy.

speaker: Doctor
text: Does the lesion feel hard or soft to touch? DIAGNOSIS READY: Skin growth needs further evaluation. Requesting skin biopsy for definitive diagnosis.
